Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.
If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg.
Too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, without draining completely, to retain some pasta water.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk and cheese mixture, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
If needed, add more reserved pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano cheese and freshly ground black pepper before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-1
outcome: Egg yolks separated and placed in a bowl
Grated pecorino romano cheese mixed with egg yolks
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl. Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Egg yolks are used in carbonara to create a creamy sauce. Pecorino Romano cheese adds flavor to the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick or the back and forth method to separate the yolks. If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcome: Bacon is cooked until crispy and cooled slightly.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooling the bacon slightly prevents overcooking the egg-based sauce that will be added later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Wait until there's no sizzle left before proceeding to ensure the bacon is not too hot.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil.
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and top with additional grated Parmigiano-Reggiano and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-1
materials: Half a pound of thick-cut bacon
outcome: Bacon is crispy and fat is rendered out
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces. Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering out the fat from the bacon makes it crispy, which is desirable for the texture and flavor in the pasta carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Turn the bacon occasionally to ensure even cooking and prevent burning.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Pasta water is seasoned with salt
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because there are many salty elements in carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: Grated cheese mixture
Whisked egg mixture
Combined egg and cheese mixture
Seasoned egg and cheese mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese. In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined. Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The cheese adds flavor and richness to the carbonara sauce. The eggs provide the creamy texture without the need for cream. Black pepper adds spice and enhances the flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a fine grater for the cheese to ensure it incorporates well into the egg mixture. Adjust the amount of black pepper according to your taste preference.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-1
outcome: Bacon is crispy and some is set aside for garnish.
Most of the bacon fat is drained, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Leaving some bacon fat in the pan will add flavor to the pasta and help emulsify the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn off the heat before draining the fat.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Spaghetti cooked to slightly al dente
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the spaghetti in the boiling water for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooking the spaghetti to slightly al dente ensures it is firm enough to hold its shape and texture when mixed with the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to handle the spaghetti after cooking. Keep the pasta water for later use in the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
materials: Bacon pan with rendered bacon fat
outcome: Spaghetti is coated with a creamy sauce made from eggs and cheese without scrambling the eggs
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The eggs are going to cook from the heat of the pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up. This ensures the eggs are not raw and the sauce is creamy.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off to prevent scrambling the eggs. Stir gently to avoid breaking the pasta. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it.

subgoal_summaries.title: Adjust and Serve-7
outcome: Pasta with a creamy sauce consistency
subgoal_summaries.instructions: If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding pasta water helps to loosen the sauce and establish a creamy consistency without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce looks too thick, adding pasta water can help achieve the desired consistency.

steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta into the boiling water to prevent sticking and cook for 8 minutes.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Optionally, crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan to infuse flavor, then remove it once the guanciale is golden.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese, then whisk together.
Once the guanciale is golden and the fat is rendered, turn off the heat.
Transfer the cooked pasta directly from the water into the pan with guanciale, using some pasta water to stop frying and create an emulsion.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing and adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce through emulsification.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Ingredients-1
outcome: Ingredients are gathered and ready for making Pasta Carbonara
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: These are the essential ingredients needed to make an authentic Pasta Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat not cut off, as you need it for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Pasta is cooked and ready for the next step
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it into the water, and put a tiny amount of salt in the water.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Twisting the pasta prevents it from sticking together. A tiny amount of salt is added because the cheese and guanciale are already salty.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a tiny amount of salt because the cheese and guanciale are salty.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-3
outcome: Guanciale is golden and fat is rendered
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and heat to medium-high to render the fat. Optionally, crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan to infuse flavor, then remove it once the guanciale is golden.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pan is started cold to render the fat out of the guanciale. The garlic is added to infuse flavor into the fat.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Start with a cold pan to effectively render the fat from the guanciale. Optionally, use garlic to add flavor but remove it once the guanciale is golden.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcome: Cracked black peppercorns with the hotter inner part sifted out
Egg and pecorino mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns. Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese, then whisk together.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The inner part of the peppercorns is hotter, which is perfect for a good hot carbonara. Eggs are delicate and need to be treated right to avoid ending up with stir-fried noodles.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a sieve to separate the milder outer skin of the peppercorns from the hotter inner part.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-3
outcome: The guanciale is golden and the fat is rendered.
The heat is turned off, stopping the frying process.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the guanciale is golden and the fat is rendered, turn off the heat. Drag the pasta and some of the pasta water into the pan with the guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Turning off the heat stops the frying process, and adding pasta water helps emulsify the fat to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the pasta water to stop the frying and help emulsify the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
outcome: Pasta is coated with a creamy sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Transfer the cooked pasta directly from the water into the pan with guanciale, using some pasta water to stop frying and create an emulsion. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing and adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce through emulsification.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water and fat from the guanciale emulsify to create a creamy sauce. The emulsification of the cooking water and fat, along with technique and timing, results in the creaminess of the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Add pasta water gradually to achieve the desired creaminess.

subgoal_summaries.title: Adjust and Serve-7
outcome: Pasta carbonara is finished with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the pasta carbonara by adding more cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more pepper and pecorino romano cheese enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more authentic and delicious.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pepper is freshly cracked for the best flavor, and use high-quality pecorino romano cheese for authenticity.

steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
In a bowl, beat two egg yolks (for two people) and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta.
Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
outcome: Spaghettoni is cooked and ready for the next step
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter. Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Salt is added to the water to enhance the flavor of the pasta. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the water is boiling before adding the pasta. Do not add oil to the water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Bacon-2
outcome: Guanciale is cut into chunks
Guanciale releases fat when cooked
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks. Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooking the guanciale in olive oil releases its fat, which is used as a base for the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use guanciale for a more authentic taste, but pancetta can be used as a substitute. Cut into big chunks for better texture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: A mixture of beaten egg yolks, cheese, and pepper, forming the base of the Carbonara sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: This mixture forms the base of the Carbonara sauce, providing creaminess and flavor without using cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add any cream to the mixture, as it is forbidden in the traditional recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-4
outcome: Pasta is mixed with the egg mixture without scrambling the eggs
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly. Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta should not be too hot when mixed with the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling, allowing them to coat the pasta smoothly.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is not too hot before adding the pasta to prevent the eggs from scrambling.

subgoal_summaries.title: Adjust and Serve-5
outcome: Pasta Carbonara is served with additional grated cheese and pepper for decoration.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Serve the pasta with additional grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and a touch of pepper for decoration.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The additional cheese and pepper serve as decoration and enhance the flavor of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Choose between parmesan or pecorino based on your preference.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Gather all necessary ingredients for Pasta Carbonara, including bacon or guanciale, cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
original_steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop and cook the bacon or guanciale until crispy, optionally infusing with garlic, and set aside.
original_steps: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Optionally, crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan to infuse flavor, then remove it once the guanciale is golden.
Once the guanciale is golden and the fat is rendered, turn off the heat.
Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil.
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Grate the cheese and mix it with eggs and black pepper to create the egg mixture.
original_steps: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks (for two people) and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
Crack black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese, then whisk together.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, add salt, and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water.
original_steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta into the boiling water to prevent sticking and cook for 8 minutes.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix the cooked pasta with bacon or guanciale, then add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring quickly to form a creamy sauce.
original_steps: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta.
Transfer the cooked pasta directly from the water into the pan with guanciale, using some pasta water to stop frying and create an emulsion.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, tossing and adding more pasta water as needed to create a creamy sauce through emulsification.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon, without draining completely, to retain some pasta water.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk and cheese mixture, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.

subgoal_definitions.title: Adjust and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Adjust the sauce consistency with reserved pasta water if needed, and finish with additional cheese and pepper before serving.
original_steps: Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.
Finish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese before serving.
If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and top with additional grated Parmigiano-Reggiano and crispy bacon.
If needed, add more reserved pasta water to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano cheese and freshly ground black pepper before serving.
